channel.title: Linux performance
channel.description:
On my home station I have recently upgraded from like a 7.04 or something ubuntu version to the newest one. I have noticed a considerable increase in the amount of RAM that is being used. I have listed below what I have done so far and am looking for other solutions to help improve my performance.
-using a light weight desktop environment now(xfce or however you spell it ) -configured my swap -started using preload -made my ram load directly from the tmp folder. -cleaned out the temporary folders/caches -downloaded compizconfigs and changed around some of the visual effects on the OS so my performance is somewhat better -start up apps have been cleaned out
I am looking for suggestions on ways to increase performance using 12.04. (pretty sure it's 12.04) ubuntu.
I have read something about disabling unity but I am not 100% sure how to do that safely. Let me explain, I run three different partitions: a windows, a windows server, and a ubuntu partition. I don't want it to affect any of my files so I want to make sure I do this properly.
So ..
1) need instructions for disabling unity as I have heard that takes up a lot of the performance/memory in the newer linux kernel for older machines such as mine 2) any other methods to help increase performance

item.title: Linux performance
item.dc:creator: @zyle1992 Zymus
item.description:
@zyle1992 wrote:

Ubuntu’s desktop environment (GNOME + Unity) are laregely memory hogs.

With those specs, I would suggest using a lightweight desktop environment, like XFCE or LXDE. Compiz is also a memory hog, because it makes the desktop look “pretty”. Sure, it can make things look cool (rain water, fire where the mouse is, etc), but doesn’t improve performance. That would be my suggestion software-wise.

If you have the ability, I would suggest increasing the amount of RAM in your machine. If it’s a Dell machine, you might have some problems, due to Dell being very picky about their hardware (adding non-Dell certified RAM might void your warranty or something).

Simply put, you could uninstall Ubuntu, and install Xubuntu (lightweight, same content), or you can just install a lightweight environment, and then remove gnome+unity.
